        public static final <E> Set<E> difference(Collection<E> left,

        Returns a collection which represents the set-theoretic difference of two other collections. This is also known as the complement (of the right argument, with regards to the left argument).
        Parameters:

        right -

      • ordered

        public static <E> List<E> ordered(Collection<E> collection,
                  Comparator<? super E> comparator)
        Returns a list containing the elements of the specified collection, ordered according to the specified comparator.
        Parameters:
        collection - the collection to order
        comparator - the comparator to determine the order of the resulting list. A null value indicates that the elements' natural ordering should be used
        Returns:
        a list ordered according to the comparator, or according to the natural ordering if no comparator is specified
        Throws:
        ClassCastException - if the collection contains elements that are not mutually comparable using the specified comparator

      • ordered

        Returns a list containing the elements of the specified collection, ordered according to the natural ordering
        Parameters:
        collection - the collection to order
        Returns:
        a list ordered according to the natural ordering
        Throws:
        ClassCastException - if the collection contains elements that are not mutually comparable (for example, strings and integers)

        Returns the smallest element of the specified collection according to the specified comparator.
        Parameters:
        collection - the collection to inspect
        comparator - the comparator to determine the order. A null value indicates that the elements' natural ordering should be used
        Returns:
        the first ordered element according to the comparator, or according to the natural ordering if no comparator is specified
        Throws:
        ClassCastException - if the collection contains elements that are not mutually comparable using the specified comparator

        Returns:

        Throws:

        Returns:

      • retain

        public static <E> Set<E> retain(Collection<E> collection,
                Predicate<? super E> predicate)
        Filters the collection according to the specified predicate, where predicate truth indicates that an object is kept. For example, 
        retain(positions, Occupied)
        will return a new set containing only the positions which are occupied.
        Parameters:
        collection - the collection
        predicate - the predicate to apply
        Returns:
        a set containing only the elements which pass the predicate

      • retain

        public static <E> List<E> retain(List<E> list,
                 Predicate<? super E> predicate)
        Filters the list according to the specified predicate, where predicate truth indicates that an object is removed. For example, 
        filter(positions, Occupied)
        will return a new list containing only the positions which are occupied.

        Applying a filter on a list maintains order.

        Parameters:
        list - the collection
        predicate - the predicate to apply
        Returns:
        a list containing only the elements which pass the predicate

      • filter

        public static <E> Set<E> filter(Collection<E> collection,
                Predicate<? super E> predicate)
        Filters the collection according to the specified predicate, where predicate truth indicates that an object is removed. For example, 
        filter(positions, Occupied)
        will return a new set containing only the positions which are unoccupied.
        Parameters:
        collection - the collection
        predicate - the predicate to apply
        Returns:
        a set containing only the elements which fail the predicate

      • filter

        public static <E> List<E> filter(List<E> list,
                 Predicate<? super E> predicate)
        Filters the list according to the specified predicate, where predicate truth indicates that an object is removed. For example, 
        filter(positions, Occupied)
        will return a new list containing only the positions which are unoccupied.

        Applying a filter on a list maintains order.

        Parameters:
        list - the collection
        predicate - the predicate to apply
        Returns:
        a list containing only the elements which fail the predicate

      • nearest

        public static <E extends Positionable> E nearest(Collection<E> collection,
                                 Positionable target)
        Finds the closest thing in a set to another given object. For example, 
        nearest(turn.tiles(), turn.actor());
        will return the nearest tile to the current actor. The set must contain objects that have a position, and the target must also have a position.
        Parameters:
        collection - A collection of objects of which to find the nearest
        target - Find the nearest object from the collection relative to this

      • furthest

        public static <E extends Positionable> E furthest(Collection<E> collection,
                                  Positionable target)
        Finds the furthest thing in a set to another given object. For example, 
        furthest(turn.tiles(), turn.actor());
        will return the furthest tile to the current actor. The set must contain objects that have a position, and the target must also have a position.
        Parameters:
        collection - A collection of objects of which to find the furthest
        target - Find the furthest object from the collection relative to this
